Suivant une interprétation du § 18 que nous aurons bientôt à apprécier, le gouvernement britannique se crut le droit strict de renoncer sans accord préalable avec les cosignataires du traité, à une clause qu'il jugerait à la fois préjudiciable à ses intérêts et sans efficacité réelle.

L'autonomie absolue que consacrerait à cet égard le § 18 pour chacun des Etats alliés parut même au Chancelier de l'Echiquier un principe tellement intangible, qu'il n'hésita point à faire valoir l'action isolée du gouvernement britannique comme un témoignage de délicatesse à l'égard de ses alliés. «De l'avis du gouvernement britannique, déclarait M. Chamberlain (28 octobre), il aurait été inutile et indésirable de chercher à faire partager sa propre responsabilité aux autres alliés, ce qui eût à la fois borné sa propre liberté d'action en vertu du traité, et lui eût donné l'air de vouloir dicter leur conduite aux autres gouvernements. » On peut croire qu'il y a dans ceci quelque exagération, et une erreur d'appréciation certaine. Car il n'est aucune Puissance alliée dont la politique puisse échapper aux répercussions de la renonciation anglaise.

Par le fait de cette renonciation, le commerce et la marine britanniques prennent une situation privilégiée; sous peine de voir s'établir au profit de ceux-ci un monopole des relations commerciales avec l'ALLEMAGNE, aucun gouvernement allié ne saurait désormais maintenir intactes toutes les garanties d'exécution offertes par le traité (1). Sans doute, il appartient, selon la thèse anglaise, à chaque gouvernement allié d'en user à sa guise et, par conséquent, d'éviter un tel préjudice en imitant l'exemple du gouvernement britannique. Mais l'on ne saurait dire que la liberté de décision de chaque Etat ait été moins atteinte par ces conséquences inéluctables de l'action isolée du gouvernement britannique, qu'elle ne l'eût été par la tentative, d'un accord préalable.

Au reste, ce point de vue avait été parfaitement apprécié par le gouvernement britannique. La question était en effet de celles que l'Angleterre « avait espéré pouvoir régler au cours de la discussion générale du problème des réparations à la conférence de Spa ou à celle qui devait avoir lieu à Genève ». Il semble que jusqu'alors il ait été tenu compte des inconvénients qu'une action isolée de l'Angleterre pouvait entraîner pour ses Alliés. « MAIS, ajoute M. CHAMBERLAIN, comme cette dernière conférence (de Genève) a été ajournée, le gouvernement britannique a trouvé impossible de maintenir une menace qui fai- () Voir en ce sens Le TEMPS, 28 octobre 1920.

sait du tort aux intérêts anglais sans offrir de réelles garanties pour l'exécution du traité. » On peut, sans désobligeance, croire que seule la déceptoin causée au gouvernement britannique par l'ajournement de la conférence de Genève détermina celuici à passer outre aux conséquences et à user du droit « strict » qu'il estimait tenir du texte du traité.
2k 2k C'est le problème proprement juridique de l'interprétation de ce texte que nous aborderons à présent.

L'interprétation du gouvernement britannique a été brièvement indiquée par M. Chamberlain dans les termes suivants : « On a critiqué le gouvernement britannique pour avoir pris cette décision sous sa propre responsabilité et sans accord préalable avec les gouvernement alliés. Mais le § 18 implique que les gouvernements respectifs sont libres de déterminer l'action qu'ils jugent nécessaires. »

Suivant le § 18, « les mesures que les Puissances alliées et associées auront le droit de prendre en cas de manquement volontaire par l'Allemagne. peuvent comprendre des actes de prohibitions et de représailles économiques et financières et en général telles autres mesures que les gouvernements respectifs pourront estimer nécessitées par les circonstances. » Entre la faculté indiquée par ce texte et la liberté totale d'action revendiquée par le gouvernement britannique la distance est appréciable à première vue. La réponse de M. Chamberlain nous laisse en présence d'un problème d'interprétation assez délicat.

Le § 18 nous apparaît comme une clause de garantie sanctionnant par un droit de représailles l'exécution par l'Allemagne de ses obligations de réparer. Dès lors, il peut sembler logique, sinon indispensable, de fixer le caractère juridique du droit principal avant de rechercher celui du droit accessoire de représailles. Pourtant cette méthode offrirait en l'espèce divers inconvénients.
C'est tout d'abord que le traité de Versailles s'est totalement obstenu de toute qualification du droit aux réparations.

On ne saurait assurément y suppléer par cette vague idée de solidarité que certains font planer comme un génie bienfaisant au-dessus des tractations de la conférence. Ramenée sous l'angle juridique, l'hypothèse d'une solidarité entre Puissances créancières de l'Allemagne est arbitraire et radicalement fausse - car aucune Puissance n'est créancière pour le tout

et l'Allemagne ne saurait valablement se libérer par le versement du montant total des indemnités entre les mains d'aucun gouvernement allié. Mais elle est de plus de nature à décevoir ceux qui précisément seraient tentés de fonder sur elle le maintien d'une coordination étroite dans l'action des Puissances alliées. La solidarité n'est point ce qu'un vain peuple pense.

Ce qui la caractérise, c'est essentiellement l'indépendance réciproque des créanciers dans la poursuite du débiteur. Cette indépendance est la conséquence nécessaire du droit de chacun à la totalité et elle en constitue l'unique manifestation - de là le droit pour chacun de recevoir et de poursuivre un paiement total. Les restrictions qu'elle subit ne vont en général point au delà de ce qui est nécessaire pour empêcher un préjudice aux cocréanciers demeurés inactifs (1). NOTAMMENT, il est loisible à chacun des créanciers de faire au débiteur remise de sa part dans la créance, ou de renoncer dans la même proportion aux sûretés fournies (2).

Ce n'est point cependant que de l'absence de toute détermination expresse du caractère juridique de l'obligation de réparer, l'on soit fondé à conclure au caractère pur et simple de cette obligation, et par conséquent à l'indépendance absolue des Puissances créancières. M. E. Clunet a fort heureusement à ce propos tiré de l'oubli relatif où elles sont tombées certaines particularités de l'obligation dite « conjointe » (3). On ne peut, en effet, mettre en doute qu'en intervenant ensemble et comme l' « une » (4) des parties à l'acte bilatéral que constitue le traité de VERSAILLES, les Puissances ont affecté de ce caractère « conjoint » leur créance vis-à-vis de l'Allemagne.

Mais cette notion juridique se trouve dans nos divers droits nationaux très inégalement développée (5); il paraît malaisé d'en tirer des conclusions généralement acceptables. Celles qu'en a déduites M. Clunet sont, à tout le moins, décevantes.

On trouve une application restreinte de cette idée dans le Code civil, articles l668 et l670. Par contre, M. Clunet relève dans LEHR, Droit civil anglais, 1885, n° 690, le principe suivant : « Lorsqu'une

« Dans un contrat - pour le moins - « conjoint » comme le traité de VERSAILLES, les stipulants fondus en une même personne juridique ne peuvent donc agir isolément pour modifier ou dénoncer tout ou partie du pacte commun. Ils ne peuvent le faire que d'accord avec leurs co-intéressés. » Oserons-nous dire que sur ce point l'argumentation de M. Clunet " nous paraît s'égarer dans un cercle vicieux ? On ne peut oublier que le gouvernement britannique n'envisage nullement sa renonciation comme une modification ou une dénonciation du traité. Et nous pensons qu'aucune Puissance ne repousserait l'idée de conjonction dans la mesure où elle l'obligerait à respecter seulement le pacte commun. Pour la solution de notre problème, la notion de conjonction n'a d'importance que si elle est capable d'imposer aux Puissances alliées une coordination dans l'exercice des droits, facultés et moyens d'action qui leur sont conférés par le traité. Que si, au contraire, elle ne suffit point à condamner l'action isolée du gouvernement britannique et que, pour aboutir à ce résultat, il faut au préalable supposer de la part de celui-ci une modification ou une dénonciation du traité, alors elle manque précisément à résoudre le seul point en litige.

Nous reconnaissons que l'idée de conjonction ou d'action conjointe des Alliés eût pu être poussée plus loin. Mais elle eût mené à des conséquences arbitraires et, probablement exagérées. Elle eût, par exemple, conduit à prohiber tout exercice isolé des sanctions prévues par le traité en cas de manquement volontaire de l'Allemagne à ses obligations (Occupation de Francfort par la FRANCE, avril-mai 1919). C'est sans doute devant de tels résultats que M. Clunet a cru devoir restreindre ses déductions.

En somme, il paraît assez périlleux de rechercher une interprétation de notre clause de garantie (§ 18) dans une détermination forcément hypothétique du caractère juridique de l'obligation principale de l'Allemagne.

Un examen direct de cette clause permet des conclusions plus sûres et plus précises. C'est que le texte du traité ne s'est point borné à formuler le principe du droit de représailles; ils soumet l'exercice de ce droit à une procédure éminemment signficative. Cette procédure constitue un élément capital d'interpromesse a été faite. à plusieurs personnes conjointement, chacun des créanciers ne peut pas rechercher séparément le débiteur dans la créance commune. L'action ne peut être intentée que par l'ensemble des créanciers et pour la dette tout entière, sauf convention contraire ou à moins que leurs intérêts respectifs ne soient absolument distincts
prétation, dont on peut s'étonner que la presse française tout au moins à notre connaissance - n'ait point fait usage.

Il est impossible de n'être pas frappé du lien étroit qui existe entre les §§ 17 et 18, - alors même qu'on ignorerait que ces deux dispositions se trouvaient, dans une rédaction première, fondues en une seule. Ce § 17 est conçu comme suit : « En cas de manquement par l'Allemagne à l'exécution qui lui incombe de l'une quelconque des obligations visées à la présente partie du présent traité, la Commission (des réparations) signalera immédiatement cette inexécution à chacune des Puissances intéressées en y joignant toutes propositions qui lui paraîtront opportunes au sujet des mesures à prendre en raison de cette inexécution. »
Si l'on rapproche cette disposition de celle du § 18 cité plus haut, on verra aussitôt que la procédure de mise à exécution du droit de représailles comporte deux phases bien distinctes.

Dans la première phase, la Commission des réparations, investie en vertu du § 12 d'un « pouvoir de contrôle » sur l'exécution des obligations de réparer qui incombent à l'ALLEMAGNE, signale à chacune des Puissances alliées tout fait constituant un manquement quelconque à ces obligations ; elle y joint « toutes propositions qui lui paraîtront opportunes au sujet des mesures à prendre. » Dans la deuxième phase, les Puissances alliées décident s'il y a manquement volontaire ou non, et dans l'affirmative prennent « telles mesures que les gouvernements respectifs pourront estimer nécessitées par les circonstances. »

La phase préparatoire est dominée par l'idée d'action commune de tous les Alliés. Organe de la solidarité des Alliés dans le problème des réparations, la Commission émet, en présence d'une infraction quelconque de l'Allemagne à ses obligations, « toutes » propositions de représailles qu'elle juge convenables (1).
Un principe radicalement différent domine la seconde phase.

Le manquement une fois signalé et les propositions transmises à « chacune » des Puissances alliées, chacune de celles-ci apprécie en toute indépendance le caractère volontaire ou non des faits et, le cas échéant, détermine en toute liberté le genre de représailles qu'il lui convient d'exercer.

(1) En fait. la Commission des réparations s'est trouvée pour une bonne part dessaisie de ses attributions telles qu'elles étaient fixées par le Traité. (R. POINCARÉ, « Chronique de la quinzaine », Revue des Deux MONDES, ler juin 1920, p.717 et s.). Mais ceci n'enlève rien à la portée juridique de l'argument.
A

ces deux phases de la procédure correspondent deux périodes dans l'existence même du droit de représailles. L'efficacité de ce droit est subordonnée à une condition suspensive : la vérification par chacune des Puissances alliées du caractère volontaire d'un manquement de la part de l'Allemagne. Tant que cette condition ne se trouve point réalisée ou défaillie à l'appréciation de l'une ou l'autre des Puissances alliées, le droit éventuel de représailles demeure constitué par l'accord des Puissances entre les mains de la Commission des réparations. Il ne saurait appartenir à aucune Puissance de réduire la portée de cette arme commune, simplement virtuelle sans doute, mais d'une évidente utilité. C'est ce qu'exprime avec force le texte du § 17 en attribuant à la Commission le droit de faire « toutes » propositions qui lui paraîtront opportunes.

Avec la vérification du caractère volontaire du manquement signalé par la COMMISSION, de virtuel le droit de représailles devient effectif. Mais il ne le devient qu'en se fractionnant, pour se fixer sur la tête de chacune des Puissances alliées et voir son exercice abandonné à l'appréciation de chacun de ses titulaires. - - En résumé, si le droit effectif ou acquis de représailles constitue une faculté individuelle dont il appartient à chaque allié d'user à sa guise (1), en revanche aucune renonciation individuelle à la menace ou droit virtuel de représailles ne paraît en principe admissible.

Cette interprétation consacre le droit « strict » pour chacune des Puissances de prendre en cas de manquement estimé volontaire de l'Allemagne à ses obligations, toute mesure qu'elle jugera nécessitée par les circonstances, et ce indépendamment de tout accord préalable avec ses alliés. A titre d'application de ce droit strict, on peut rappeler l'occupation de Francfort par la (1) Les droits « acquis » aux Puissances alliées sont des droits individuels dont chacune d'elles dispose suivant son bon plaisir : tel paraît être le principe général dont s'inspire le Traité. C'est ainsi que chaque Puissance demeure libre d'exercer ou non le droit « acquis » en vertu de l'article 297, b, « de retenir et de liquider tous les biens droits et intérêts appartenant, à la date de la mise en vigueur du présent TRAITÉ, à des ressortissants allemands ». Mais on ne saurait tirer de là aucun argument pour justifier une renonciation isolée au droit simplement éventuel de représailles. La différence n'avait pas échappé au gouvernement britannique. Répondant, en effet, à une question qui signalait que le gouvernement français avait fait précisément la même chose que le gouvernement britannique en renonçant à la saisie des biens bulgares en FRANCE,

M. Chamberlain s'exprima comme suit : « NON, pas précisément la même chose. Je n'ai pas à justifier notre action, qui est justifiable, en la comparant à l'action prise au sujet de la Bulgarie.Le TEMPS, 3 novembre l920.)

France pendant les mois d'avril-mai 1920. D'autre part, elle tend à condamner l'action isolée du gouvernement britannique renonçant à un droit virtuel de représailles constitué au profit du groupe des alliés. .
Ces conclusions découlent à notre sens avec certitude de la procédure établie par les § § 17 et 18 pour l'exercice du droit de représailles. Cette argumentation est-elle absolument décisive !

Nous ne le croyons pas. Car enfin si cette procédure traduit bien les intentions générales des PUISSANCES, d'autres éléments peuvent faire obstacle à une application intégrale et intransigeante du système et justifier quelque tolérance. - L'étendue même du droit de représailles, son indétermination totale, pourrait à cet égard soulever des hésitations. Sans doute le § 18, où cette indétermination s'étale de façon mena- çante vis-à-vis de l'ALLEMAGNE, est relatif au droit effectif de représailles; il vise à faire d'avance reconnaître par l'Allemagne la légitimité de toute mesure de représailles en même temps qu'il réserve à chacune des Puissances alliées une liberté entière dans l'exercice de ce droit. Mais cette indétermination affecte aussi nécessairement le droit virtuel de représailles ; c'est même ce qui aux yeux des Puissances alliées devait constituer sa meilleure force. OR, s'il est vrai qu'en principe ce droit virtuel est une arme commune, si son mode de constitution implique pour chacune des puissances l'obligation de ne rien faire qui puisse en compromettre l'efficacité, cependant, comment cette obligation se soutiendra-t-elle devant l'étendue sans limite des droits communs à respecter ? Peut-on concevoir que clhaque Puissance ait contracté l'engagement absolu de ne prendre aucune mesure susceptible de réduire les possibilités illimitées de représailles stipulées par le traité de Versailles à l'encontre de l'Allemagne ? Des engagements d'une telle amplitude ne doivent pas être présumés à charge d'une Puissance souveraine. Cette observation prend un poids singulier si l'on considère que la disposition primitive, à laquelle se sont substitués les § § 17 et 18, contenait une énumération exemplative des mesures de représailles, qu'en l'effaçant les Puissances alliées l'ont remplacée par la formule générale que l'on sait, et " y ont ajouté une clause nouvelle réservant expressément la liberté d'action des gouvernements respectifs.

Faute d'objet déterminé avec une précision suffisante, l'obligation se trouve affaiblie; ce qu'elle gagne en étendue, elle le perd en vigueur; il paraît difficile d'en poursuivre l'exécution rigoureuse. Et l'on conçoit qu'une puissance.renonçant seulement à l'un des modes possibles de représailles, proteste
de sa fidélité à l'esprit du Traité en se fondant sur la multiplicité des moyens d'action qui demeurent en son pouvoir (1).

Cette thèse apparaît soutenable, à une condition toutefois : c'est que le mode particulier de représailles dont il est fait abandon par l'une des Puissances alliées ne constitue point le mode de représailles par excellence, ou l'un de ceux que les Puissances signataires ont dû nécessairement avoir en vue au moment de la conclusion du Traité. Cette condition négative se trouve-t-elle remplie ? On en peut très sérieusement douter. Car d'une part, la saisie des biens ennemis figure traditionnellement en première ligne parmi les actes de représailles (2). Et d'autre part, l'énumération exemplative des mesures de représailles que comportait la rédaction primitive à laquelle il a été fait allusion, contenait une clause visant expressément la saisie de ces biens. Si donc, la volonté commune des Puissances alliées s'est implicitement fixée sur l'éventualité d'une telle mesure, il est clair qu'aucune des parties ne saurait se prévaloir de l'indétermination qui affecte le texte pour échapper à l'obligation de maintenir intacte la menace que cette éventualité particulière fait peser sur l'Allemagne.

Tel est, en définitive, le point d'où dépend la décision du problème. Malheureusement les éléments que nous possédons ne permettent point un avis catégorique. Car si la saisie des biens ennemis constitue en quelque sorte le prototype des actes de représailles, on ne saurait oublier que la mention qui en fut faite d'abord disparut par la suite. Et nous ne voyons rien qui permette de décider si la formule générale qui lui fut substituée avait davantage pour but d'élargir la menace au regard de l'ALLEMAGNE, ou de relâcher les obligations que la clause pouvait faire naître entre alliés - quoique la dernière hypothèse nous paraisse plus vraisemblable.

() C'est ce que fit valoir lord CURZON, au cours des explications échangées avec l'ambassade de France à Londres : « Le gouvernementbritan nique n'a renoncé aucunement aux sanctions qui pourraient être prises vis-à-vis de l'État allemand en cas de manquement volontaire à ses obligations relatives aux réparations ». (Le TEMPS, l° novembre l920) Voir dans le même sens une note officieuse de l'Agence Reuter (Le TEMPS, 30 octobre 1920) : La « renonciation à tel droit individuel n'implique en aucune façon une revision ni une rectification » du Traité « et ne diminue pas non plus les moyens de contraindre l'Allemagne en cas de manquement volontaire à ses engagements ».
() VATTEL, L. lI, chap. XVIII, § 344; BONFILs et FAUCHILLE, MANUEL, n° 980. --
2k :: k A défaut d'une interprétation absolument sûre, il ne sera point sans profit de rechercher les causes de cette ambiguité.
Les §§ 17 et 18 poursuivent manifestement un double objectif.

D'une part, par l'établissement d'un droit de représailles aussi étendu que possible, ils tendent à garantir l'exécution des obligations de l'Allemagne. D'autre part, la procédure qu'ils indiquent vise à maintenir dans toute son énergie l'effet préventif de ce droit. Ce dernier résultat ne pouvait être atteint qu'en constituant ce droit sur la tête d'un organisme interallié, au prix, par conséquent, d'une limitation notable de la liberté d'action de chacune des Puissances alliées. Mais de telles restrictions à l'autonomie d'une puissance ne sont pratiquement tolérables qu'à la condition d'être rigoureusement circonscrites. En sorte que l'étendue même de la menace formulée à l'encontre de l'Allemagne s'est trouvé compromettre la solidité de son maintien par toutes les Puissances. Le vice de ces dispositions est assurément de poursuivre deux objectifs dont les exigences sont contradictoires. - En ce qui concerne la menace générale de représailles formulée à l'encontre de l'ALLEMAGNE, on peut certes apprécier le souci qu'ont eu les alliés d'assurer par une convention expresse la légitimité des moyens de contrainte qu'ils pourraient se trouver amenés à exercer. Mais pareille clause était-elle indispensable pour justifier l'application de sanctions rigoureuses en cas de manquement « volontaire » de la part de l'Allemagne ?

En tant qu'elle vise la saisie des biens ennemis cette menace explicite présente en tout cas l'inconvénient de réduire à néant la matière saisissable. Il paraît difficile de contester sur ce point l'appréciation du gouvernement britannique.

Mais le principe d'une telle clause une fois admis, c'est seulement par un acte distinct du Traité que le maintien par tous les alliés d'un ensemble de moyens de coercition pouvait être efficacement assuré. De cette façon les engagements pris à cet égard par les Puissances alliées auraient pu être déterminés avec une précision rigoureuse, sans que l'on eût à craindre de réduire par là la portée générale de la menace de représailles formulée à l'encontre de l'Allemagne.
FERNAND DE VISSCHER.
Professeur à l'Université de Gand.
II
THE PORTSMOUTH CONFERENCE

The Twenty-ninth Conference of the International Law Association was held on the 27"-3l* May in this year, under the presidency of the Right Hon. the Earl of READING, the Lord Chief Justice of England. This Conference will be memorable as the first truly international assembly to meet after the war. It is true that only one member of the late enemy States actually attended.

The absence of those who desired to attend was undoubtedly owing to the heavy cost of travel due to the rate of exchange, and to the poor travelling facilities. - Every effort was made by the Executive Council through their CHAIRMAN, Lord PHILLIMORE, to facilitate the entry of late enemy members into this country, and owing to Lord Phillimore's exertions, permits were obtained from the Home Office for all those who intimated their intention of being present.
Members from numerous neutral States and delegates representing various national Red Cross SOCIETIES, created an atmosphere favourable to the impartial discussion of international questions.

Sir Henry Maine in view of the comparative failure of the Brus sels CONFERENCE, l874, expressed the opinion that International Conferences should not be held until the passions created by war, had had time to cool down. This opinion was not shared by the Executive Council which felt that no time should be lost in convening a CONFERENCE, which was fixed to take place at Portsmouth in OCTOBER, l9l9. Although all the arrangements had been made, it was found necessary to postpone the meeting on account of the Railway Strike in Fngland.

The Conference was opened by the Mayor of PORTSMOUTH, Councillor T. TIMPSON, J. P., who welcomed the members and pointed out that it was the duty of everyone to do all that was possible to bring about peace and good feeling between different countries and their peoples. - Dr. JITTA, President of the ASSOCIATION, in thanking the Mayor for his hospitality, said that the Association in its life of nearly half a century had performed valuable work for the Codification of the Law of Nations and the Development of International LAW, which had prepared the way for the League of Nations.

The Earl of Reading as President of the CONFERENCE, struck the keynote in his inaugural address upon the League of Nations. He expressed his belief that lnternational Law would never completely recover from the blow it had received during the war, unless the League of Nations became an effective organisation to enforce the law in the future BUT, although International Law was defied by force of arms, it still retained a moral value of inestimable worth to the Allies during thegreat struggle. He contrasted the work of international jurists during the last halt century in the field of peaceful settlement of disputes by arbitration with the contemporaneous competition in armaments which culminated in the catastrophy of AUGUST, l9l4.

In the former work the International Law Association had played its part. From the havoc of war - havoc among the victors as well as among the vanquished and in a lesser degree among the neutrals - we understand what a Great War means. Its lesson has been borne in upon us and as a result has come to birth that epoch-making document, the Covenant of the League of Nations.

An imperfect instrument no doubt, but nevertheless, a document of world importance. It is true that it has not yet been ratified by all the nations, and whether the United States of America would do so, was not for us to judge. But whether the United States ratified or not. she would, he was convinced, remain a supporter of justice and liberty in the future as she had been in the past, and that those nations associated in the LEAGUE, would be able to rely upon her when they formulated conclusions based upon reason and upon justice.
It was not sufficient that the League of Nations should remain merely a conception, it must become an effective organisation.

This will depend not upon statesmen, politicians, and international jurists, however eminent, but must in the last resort depend for its strength upon the opinion of the vast majority of the peoples of mankind.

Of the many Commissions set up to enquire into questions of international interest other than that for the prevention ofwar, one of the most important was the Commission to devise a plan for the Permanent Court of International Justice. But whether the League of Nations succeeds in its ultimate aim or not, the mere fact of agreements between nations to hold CONFERENCES, to set up Commissions and to discuss questions of international interest, is in itself of inestimable value.
To found a Court of Justice was not so difficult, but to enforce its decrees was a much more difficult problem. The League
should not attempt too much. The Court of Justice must achieve prestige by the justice of its decisions and that would take time.
That the League would prevent some was beyond all question, but there might be some matters which the League could not settle.

Even in that case there would be a moral value in the influence of the League which would have its effect upon the world. PERSONALLY, he would, rather have an arbitration award which was unsatisfactory, than a war with all its triumphs, which gave everything desired. - - During the war, whether at the front or at home, menand women, old and young, registered a deep and solemn vow that such a war should never happen again. These vows must not be lost.

Believing as we do that the very existence of lnternational Law depends so largely upon the League of Nations this vow must be . carried into effect at all costs, save that of the honour and security of a nation. We must lend our strength to the support of the LEAGUE, to breathe life into it, to stimulate those who are working for it, and so gradually bring about a reign of reason based upon justice, which will enable us to say in truth as well as in words, that justice among men reigns at last supreme.

In voicing the thanks of the meeting to the Earl of Reading for his eloquent address, the Bishop of Winchester said that the applause with which it was greeted showed the appreciation of those present for the endorsement which the Presidend had given to the practical value of the League of Nations.

He referred to the visit of Lord Reading to the United States at a moment when this country wished to express through him the intensity of its desire that Great Britain and the United States should stand side by side in the defence and maintenance of the peace of the world.
The League of Nations appealed to the conscience of the nations.

It appealed to whatever is ideal in our hearts. Cynics might scoff at the word « ideal -, but we had had in the war a mighty lesson of the power of ideals. We had seen what it was to have a false ideal, and what might could gather about it, and with what energy it could launch a people upon a wrong course; but we had also seen the weakness of a false ideal when it came into contact with an ideal which was true. One danger to the common cause was that everybodys business is nobodys business, and that was why he with the MAYOR, welcomed the visit of the International Law Association and that was why he rejoiced to find that such a body representing different nations of the world, put on the very front of its programme, and emphasised with all the eloquence and
authority that its President could command, the importance of the League of Nations.

2k The first paper presented to the Conference was that of the Right Hon. Sir Frederick POLLOCK, Bart., K. C., entitled - The Lawyers'Place in the League of Nations », in which he pointed out that there were two ways in which the League of Nations required intelligent assistance. The one by interpretation, the other by the enlightment of public opinion.

Interpretation was eminently the business of lawyers. In such interpretation, not only of the Covenant itself, but of many international documents, lawyers were capable of giving material - assistance.

Legal training was the best in arriving at a common sense view of a document as a whole in ascertaining what it really means. In his opinion the people who raised quibbles and captious points, were not the lawyers but the politicians who knew nothing of law.

As a precedent for the interpretation of the Covenant he referred to the interpretation ofthe Constitution of the United States by the Supreme Court. The enlightment of public opinion was perhaps more urgent, although doubtless this could be achieved to a very considerable extent by intelligent laymen. At the same time it was the business of lawyers to know something about exposition.

A League of Nations could not exist without visible force, but after all, a public force itself ultimately rested on public opinion, especially when it was a new public force. CONSEQUENTLY, the right kind of public opinion must be established.
In a powerful speech the Right Hon. C. A. Mc CURDY, K. C.,

M. P., the minister of FOOD, advocated the abolition of the laws of war and the code which recognises the rights or priviliges of neutrals. An aggressive war should be regarded as an international crime and as a corollary to that doctrine, in the presence of crime, no self-respecting nation could afford to remain neutral.
He contended that the real security for life and property within the State was not the sanction of the Criminal Code but the moral conscience of the Community.

In presenting his paper entitled « The Press and the League of Nations -, M. Thomas Cox Meech explained that the press depended for its existence upon, and was the reflection, of the spirit and tone of public opinion. He appealed to the League of Nations to provide material whereby the press might assist the League.
In a paper entitled - The Work of Religious Bodies », Canon A.

Bickersteth Ottley dwelt upon the influence of Christianity under International Law and with the practical lessons which could be drawn in connection with the League of Nations and the work of the Churches.

HISTORY, he declared, had proclaimed that it was to the Christian Church that the world must look for supplying the League of Nations with that vitalising spiritual energy which alone could bring the ideals of the Covenant into the sphere of popular acceptance and pratical achievement.

By common assent the one outstanding lesson of the Great War was that the problem of the world peace was one of moral and spiritual values; that the key to its solution must be sought not in codes and treaties, not in economics or diplomacy, still less in colossal armaments, but in the sphere of ethics ; in which free and willing acceptance by the nations of the world of the moral law is the supreme and final authority for the regulation of national and international disputes, for the progressive reduction of armaments, and for the permanent avoidance of war Tested by Christian standards, the League of Nations was replete with Christian ideals and principles. The objects defined in the preamble derived all their authority and value from Christian sanctions and in all the twenty-six articles the same high ethical standards were consistently maintained.

A great and protracted educational effort was called for on the part, not only of the CHURCHES, but of all the leaders of the organised spiritual and moral forces of the country. It rested with the Churches to mobilise these forces and to reinforce the splendid efforts of international law in the endeavour to create and maintain a sound public opinion upon the principles ofthe League of Nations.
It was therefore for the Churches to respond to the invitation ofthe International Law Association to assist in its high endeavour.
In his paper entitled « Education and Unity of Mankind »,

Mr F. S. Marvin considered some of the ways in which the actual process of educating the young might be used to implant and to fortify the sense of oneness in mankind. It is true that there are already in existence some facilities for an educational internationalism. But he desired to call attention rather to the possibilities contained in the ordinary subjects of instruction for an international training. Of these ordinary subjects, history and science were the most suitable.
The teaching of history to children had been far too narrow and devoted almost exclusively to the political side. No one had ever

attempted to teach our children the history of man as MAN, with all his early struggles and trials, his spreading over the globe, his specialisation in tribes and nations, his conquest of nature, his creation to ART, his building up of Science.

Science is obviously international. The oneness of science might therefore be used with some effect to create and sustain that will for the oneness of a League of NATIONS, upon which we must rely in order to withstand the tendencies to narrower exclusiveness.

The League must be prepared to exploit and to widen the sense of this oneness of human science and the world patriotism which is latent in it. The League must consciously take these forces under its direction and use them as instruments for creating a will to human unity. The full development of the international organisation of science could only be performed adequately by a League representing the union of all nations and peoples.

Dealing with the failure of the Senate of the United States to ratify the Treaty of Peace between the various Allied POWERS, including the United States and GERMANY, Mr. Everett P.WHEELER, of the Bar of the Supreme Court of the United STATES, reviewed the situation as affected by the American Constitution.
He traced the development in the United States of the conviction that that country should take an active part in the formation and should itself become a party to, the League of Nations.

The Covenant of the League had been rejected by a majority of the SENATE, but it was not dead. On the contrary, it had been ratified by many of the nations whose representatives made it, and many neutrals had become members of the LEAGUE, which was now in full operation.

He was optimistic enough to declare his belief that the United States would not finally refuse to join in this international LEAGUE, the Covenant of which, as he showed, was a natural development of those principles to which the United States had frequently and formally expressed its adhesion.

It was not surprising therefore to find such a body as the Chamber of Commerce of the State of NEWYork in DECEMBER, l9l9, adopting a Report which deprecated the action of the Senate in refusing ratification of the Treaty. - The truth is -, Mr. Wheeler declared, « that the United States finds itselfin the position of a man whose judgment has been convinced of the justice and truth of a certain proposition, but who shrinks from its logical consequences when he first perceives just what they are. This hesitation is not unnatural in a democracy.
We trust that our European friends will have patience with us and that the Treaty will yet be ratified by the Senate of the United States. »

In criticising Mr. Wheeler's paper, Sir Graham Bower said that we all agreed that the reign of law must supersede the reign of violence. But although we were all agreed about the end, we were not all agreed about the means to the end.

The one point common to all the speeches delivered in the American Senate against the League of Nations was that the one way to peace was to mind our own business. There were two schemes to avoid war. The one, by system of arbitration; the other by creation of the Super-State.

The former is based upon law, the latter upon politics. The national record of the United States about this question had been consistent. It had never varied from the support of arbitration as a means of settling international disputes and in l909 through Secretary KNOX, the United States had asked for a Permanent Court of International Justice.

Mr. Ira Brainerd referred to the misunderstanding of the position of the League of Nations in the United States by many people here, who accused the United States of being indifferent or even hostile to the League. This misunderstanding was largely due to the mixed nature of American nationality. The Americans were not indifferent to these questions, and wherever you went you would find every place full of amateur international lawyers discussing it.

In a striking paper entitled « Disarmament », Major David DAVIES, M. P., said that the League of Nations must be provided with a force under its direct control which could be employed without the least delay against any State defying its authority.

He suggested the creation of an International Police Force. Each nation would continue to possess forces sufficient for the maintenance of internal order and for its quota of the International Police Force.
The vital question in « Disarmament - was the elimination of competition in armaments. This competition had become rather a competition in scientific invention.

Major Davies suggested that the weapons of all national armaments should be reduced to a common standard, e. g the rifle and bayonet, machine gun, cavalry sword and lance, field artillery and the smaller types of war vessels. All weapons the result of recent and future scientific invention, such as tanks, heavy artillery, submarines, poison gas and war planes, should be under the control
of the League of NATIONS, to be used solely by the International - Police Force under their control.

THUS, the great evil of competition in armaments might be eliminated. This highly specialised International Police Force would be distributed to different strategic world points. While the International Police Force would never interfere with the internal affairs of any country, backed by the quotas furnished by the members of the LEAGUE, it would render futile any single or combined attempts to disobey the decisions of the League.

Major Davies moved the following resolution : « That this Conference considers that the League of Nations should examine the Project of an International Police Force to which each country should contribute its quota, which should have sole control of all recent and future scientific control of armaments. »

In seconding the resolution, Senator Albert LEJEUNE, referred to the position of BELGIUM, which for centuries had been the battlefield of Europe. It appeared to him pending the moral - re-making mankind », that the effectiveness of the League of Nations could not become real without some proper force as Policeman of the - world. . - Objection having been taken to the resolution by Sir Graham BOWER, Mr. J. Arthur Barratt moved : « That this Conference considers that the League of Nations should examine the Project of an International Police Force . » - This was seconded by the Lord Chief JUSTICE, who said there should not be any objection to examining such a Project. It was a subject of very great importance and it was desirable that the League of Nations should examine it. The Resolution was carried unanimously.

In presenting his Paper on - The Revision of the League of Nations Covenant », Mr. F. N. KEEN, LL. B., moved : - That in the opinion of this Conference it is expedient that the League of Nations should appoint a Standing Commission to consider questions relating to the Revision of the Covenant and to advise the League thereon. »

He contended that a Standing Committee within the League would ensure the careful and competent examination of proposals for revision o1 the Covenant before they come into the arena of the Assembly for formal discussion.
SECONDLY, such a Committee would probably avoid the risk of the time and attention of the Assembly being unduly occupied in the consideration of questions relating to the constitution of the League.
LASTLY,

such a Commission would be an appropriate body to consider the criticisms which have been raised upon the Covenant in the United States and would ensure the careful and adequate consideration of any objections to the provisions of the Covenant.

Mr. J. Arthur Barratt asked whether it was not possible, for the League as already constituted to do everything suggested in the Resolution. - Mr. Wyndham A. Bewes feared that the Covenant would fail, not because it went too far, but because it did not go far enough and was not empowered to deal adequately with the causes which lead to war.

The Lord Chief Justice said that it appeared to him undesirable that the International Law ASSOCIATION, meeting for the first time after the war and celebrating the formation of a League of Nations should simultaneously record a resolution indicating that it required amendment.
The subjects discussed upon the motion, were of the vastest importance, involving questions which went far beyond the power of the Standing Committee to investigate.

MOREOVER, there was no necessity for the RESOLUTION, since the power to appoint a Standing Commission was inherent in the constitution of the League. He suggested therefore that Mr. Keen should withdraw his resolution, a suggestion which was at once adopted by the author of the paper. « The Scope of Mandates under the League of Nations « is the title of an exceedingly valuable and suggestive paper by Mr. Leonard WOOLF, in which the author drew attention to the very limited powers which will be exercised in the mandated territories of the Ottoman EMPIRE, as compared with those over the German possessions in Africa and the Pacific.

With regard to the latter, the whole object of the Mandatory must be the material prosperity and welfare of the native population, which can only be obtained by educating the native to take first place as a free man in the government of his own country.
The economic exploitation of the natives must be stopped. The natives must be reinstated in their lands, and forced labour must be rendered impossible.

He suggested that the following conditions should be imposed upon the administration of Mandatories : l. The Mandatory Government must encourage and educate the native communities to make the most economic use of their land by every possible means, and in particular by providing agricultural education, expert instructors, model farms, etc.
2. Primary schools must be provided in sufficient numbers to make it possible for every native child to obtain primary education.
Training colleges for native teachers must be provided.

3. Higher and technical education must be provided with a view to educating natives not only to become doctors, agricultural experts and instructors, etc., but also to fill administrative posts in the government of the country. - « The Permanent Court of International Justice », was the subject of a paper by Mr. Justice B. C. J. Loder of the Supreme Court of the NETHERLANDS, who, with Lord PHILLIMORE, Senator Elihu ROOT, and other jurists, was one of the Committee of the League of Nations to prepare a scheme for such a Court.
The learned judge laid down the following principles which ought to be observed in the creation of the new Court :
FIRST, all States should be equal and the choice ofjudges by the Assembly should be by a majority of votes ;

SECONDLY, jurisdiction of the judges should be that of a Permanent Court before which the adverse party might be cited, independent of its will and under an obligation to submit to sentence of the Court. The distinction between jurisdiction and arbitration must be clearly drawn;
THIRDLY, the Court must be kept free from all political influence ;
FOURTHLY, the independence of the Judges must be secured.
In reply to a question by Mr. R. S. FRASER, Judge Loder said that in his own opinion parties other than States should be entitled to come before the Court.
The Lord Chief Justice said that they were all agreed with the fundamental principal propositions laid down by Mr. Justice Loder.

The Association was indebted to him for the presentation of such a thoughtful paper upon this almost the most difficult subject of all that they had to consider The independence of the judges was vital. But the proposed judges must also be impartial Impartiality was comparatively easy for the judges when dealing with municipal law, but their position was rather more difficult in an international court.

The international judge would have to say to himself : « Now be careful no to be influenced too much in favour of that in which you have grown up. - His greatest difficulty would be to distinguish between his national bias and his reason.

The Conference on the Laws of War at Sea was presided over by His EXCELLENCY, Mr. J. W DAVIS, the American Ambassador. In his opening address, the Ambassador said that in accepting the invitation to the Conference he seized the occasion to voice the deep and abiding interest of America in the growth, enthronement and supremacy of International Law.

The differences of opinion in the United States must not be taken as evidence of any unwillingness on their part to join the free peoples of the world in establishing just rules for international conduct, founded in reason and sanctioned by the common approval of mankind.

Two schools of thought had obstructed the advance of International Law. ONE, that of extreme nationalism, which regarded the individual State as unlimited in authority and exempt from the ordinary cannons of right and wrong. The other school, no less destructive than that of the extreme nationalist, who can see virtue in every nation but his own, and which was unable to distinguish between humanitarian and legal doctrines.

Was it not Chief Justice Coke who said that it was almost as important to human happiness that law should be certain as that it should be just. With the experience of the Great WAR, no one could doubt the necessity for some common understanding on the Laws of War at Sea.
The keynote might be found in the following passage from the Report of the Maritime Law Committee : « Belligerents have not an unlimited right of choice of methods of injuring the enemy. »

It was said that modern warfare had become a struggle between whole peoples, and that there was no longer any distinctionbetween combatants and non-combatants. This was a reversion, under the pretence of changed conditions, to the most primeval savagery.

Apart from reprisals, what justification could be offered for the indiscriminate bombing of cities, towns and villages, the bombardment of undefended sea-coasts, and above all for the wilful drowning at sea of non-combatant seamen and voyagers ?

Of all the horrors of the recent war, the one which will linger longest, in the minds of men and leave the most indelible stain upon its authors, was the unrestricted submarine warfare, and the sinking without succour of helpless men, harmless women and innocent children. - The Report of the British Maritime Law Committee embodying a draft code of the Laws of War at Sea was framed without reference to the creation of a League of Nations. Now that the

League has been established, some changes in the Draft will be necessary. The Draft is based on the Oxford Manual of Naval WAR, adopted by the Institute of International Law in 1913, and upon the Hague Conventions and the Declaration of London.
The Draft is not, however, a mere consolidation of previous rules.
Wherever experience of the War has shown that a change from the exact rules had become necessary, the Committee have not - hesitated to take their own line.

In addition to new proposals with regard to contraband and blockade, one of which is the adoption of the doctrine of continuous voyage, the Committee recommended that unrestricted submarine " warfare against private vessels should be prohibited, and the destruction of neutral merchantmen should be altogether prohibited, unless they resisted visit and search, engaged in running a blockade, or were guilty of unneutral service.

The Committee also recommended that the officer responsible for the illegal destruction of a merchant vessel, should be regarded as a war criminal and should be liable to punishment as such if captured.

The necessity for taking merchantmen into port for search was recognised, but it was proposed that neutral ship should be entitled to payment of demurrage if the search did not disclose valid reason for detention. . The provisions providing for the immunity of hospital ships were strenghtened. - On question of the right of private vessels to arm the Committee were divided.

In presenting the Report as Chairman of the COMMITTEE, Sir John Macdonell said that the one question which stood on the threshold of any discussion was whether there were to be any neutrals in the future, whether neutrality was to be a recognised status ? If so, what are to be the duties pertaining thereto ?
When all the chief States of the world had become members of the LEAGUE, there might be no neutrals and questions of contraband and blockade which presuppose neutrality would not arise.

But that time seemed to him to be very far off and in the meantime the problem remained, what are to be the rights of belligerents and neutrals ? - Sir Graham Bower moved the following amendment viz. that : « All armed vessels should be treated as combatants, and all unarmed vessels as non-combatants. The latter should not be liable to destruction and should not engage in hostilities by ramming or otherwise. -
After some discussion the amendment was rejected.

Rear Admiral S. S. Hall advocated the abolition of the use of the torpedo. All the rules for restricting the use of the submarine or for restricting the arming of merchant ships, will be valueless if the submarine is allowed to use the torpedo against merchantmen.
Mr. H. F. MANISTY, K. C., supported this proposal.

Dr. Bisschop moved, and Dr. Bellot seconded. « That in view of the cessation of hostilities. that the word - British - be dropped from the title of the British Maritime Law COMMITTEE, and that members of other nations, other than BRITISH, should be added, and that the Report be recommitted to the Committee. - This proposal was adopted. - In his paper on - Sequestration of Neutral Merchantmen -,

Dr K. Jansma pointed out that during the war he had endeavoured to secure the adoption of a scheme under which the destruction of neutral prizes should be replaced by a guaranteed and recognised sequestration in a neutral port until the conclusion of the war.
His proposals were rejected by the German Government and.had therefore become a question of post-war reform. He suggested that the Maritime Law Committee should take his paper into consideration.
The Right Hon. Lord Justice Younger presided over the Conference upon Treatment of Prisoners of War.

In his opening address Lord Justice Younger said that the importance of this question could not be exaggerated If only by the reason of the fact that all international agreements on this subject in existence at the outbreak of the war and then binding on all the combatants, as well as the high professions as to the usages of war in this matter published in advance by the principal contending States as binding on their conscience, were all of them powerless to prevent innumerable notorious instances of suffering, undeserved, gratuitous, heart-rending beyond expression, which thousands of prisoners had to endure through those tragic years of horror.
The outstanding phenomenon of the war was the almost immediate repudiation, mainly by our enemies, of the solemn promises and obligations on this great subject.
He referred to the difficulties which experience had shown beseting this subject, the first of which was the difference between - public opinion in peace time, and public opinion in time of war.
In modern warfare there is a tendency in all governments, depen-
dent as they are on popular support, to treat their prisoners as criminals and not as defenceless captives.
Another difficulty arose from agreements with reference to Prisoners of War made in time of peace without reference to the opinion of the military leaders.

AGAIN, the wholesale exchange of prisoners of war would put an end, once and for all, to the large amount of suffering necessarily incidental to the position of a prisoner-of-war. But the military believe that the risk of such arrangements, which might not be observed by the enemy, is too great.

In considering proposals therefore for the treatment of prisoners of war, care must be taken to see that nations were not in advance committed to any proposals which their people or their High Command might in time of war induce them, if they could, to renounce Another notable lesson of the war is the enormous advantage to prisoners of war which is secured by direct communication between representatives of the belligerents while war is actually proceeding.

He referred to the Anglo-German Agreements of l9l7-1918 and also to the indiscriminate internment of civilian prisoners of war Such internment before the war was generally regarded as prohibited. But except in Austria and Hungary it became general in all belligerent countries.
But we ought not to forget the great difference there is between the position of a combatant prisoner of war and that of a civilian.
He suggested that the internment or compulsory repatriation of civilian enemies should only be carried .. out if their liberty and presence appeared to be dangerous to the safety of the State.
In their paper entitled « The Treatment of Prisoners of War -,

Mr. Phillimore and Dr. Bellot pointed out that the experience of the war had shown the urgent need for revision of the status of prisoners of war, for which the existing rules had admittedly proved inadequate and had had to be supplemented by special agreements between the belligerents. They urged that no more fitting time for their consideration was to be found than the present, when the expression of their shortcomings was fresh in the mind.

A novel and somewhat startling suggestion of the authors was the transfer of prisoners to the province of the civil administration, which would definitely mark them as assigned to civil employment and to work of a non-military character. Was it impracticable to suggest that prisoners of war should definitely
lose their combatant status and either be sent home on parole or interned in a neutral country ?
Some regulations were also suggested by the authors.

Mr. Phillimore said that the difficulties which Lord Justice Younger had placed before them were all the more additional reason for the Association to undertake the revision of the Laws of War upon the Treatment of Prisoners of War. The divergencies between military and naval opinions on the one side, and those of civilians and lawyers on the other must be reconciled in some way. Experience had shown that the Hague CONVENTIONS, although infringed in many respects, were of value as an established code to which both parties could refer and by which they could claim to be judged. He recognised the difficulties in the way of the proposal that prisoners on capture should lose their military status. Under the changed conditions of modern warfare he thought the proposal was worthy of consideration.

Dr. Bellot said he entirely agreed with Lord Justice Younger that we should not attempt to frame regulations which will either . be opposed now by the military authorities in various countries or will not be observed by belligerents when war actually breaks out.
At the same time, he for one, was not willing to bow the knee unreservedly to the doctrine of military necessity. .

Some regulations there must be. The policy of frightfulness is a natural sequence to the doctrine of military necessity. But the war had proved that the policy of frightfulness does not pay even from the military point of view. There must be an agreement upon general principles before regulations can be framed.

The first of these principles was the recognition of the old distinction between combatants and non-combatants. To abolish these distinctions would be a degenerate step and so far from preventing war, it would stimulate the spirit of militarism. « The nations in arms - theory was in his view untenable.
FURTHER, combatants who surrendered should in no case be - killed. HOSPITALS, hospital ships and their personnel should be immune. Prisoners of War must always be humanely treated.
FINALLY, labour required by a prisoner should only be that which he is capable of performing and in its amount should be reasonable.

Sir Reginald ACLAND, K. C., expressed his opposition to the proposal that prisoners of war on capture should cease to be regarded as combatants, on the ground that it was impossible to keep large bodies of prisoners in order except they were under military law.

Mr. Henriques moved, and Lord Phillimore seconded : - That the question of Treatment of Prisoners of war and of interned civilian enemies be referred to a Committee to be appointed by the Executive Council. This Committee shall also be empowered as it thinks fit to consider the question of the deportation of ' interned civilian enemies. - The Resolution was carried unanimously.

At the conclusion of the sitting, Lord Justice Younger referred to the services rendered to our prisoners of war by the good offices of the neutral STATES, services which could never be repaid or sufficiently acknowledged. We could never forget the services rendered by the Queen of HOLLAND, the King of SPAIN, the Swiss Confederation and by Mr. GERARD, before the United States came into the Conflict. k:

At the Conference upon - International Co-operation under the League of Nations -, Lord Phillimore was in the CHAIR, and before opening the proceedings proposed that the Association should deposit a wreath in memory of the gallant sailors of both sides who fell at Jutland. Seconded by Dr. JITTA, the motion was carried unanimously, and Lord Phillimore deposited the wreath on the Cenotaphe on the steps of the Town Hall in the name of the Association.
In his address, Lord Phillimore alluded to the constructive work of the various international organisatîons enumerated by Dr. SCHUSTER, Mr. WOOLF, and other speakers.

So far as these Unions were matters of law, treaty and government, he thought it very desirable that they should all be brought into the office and workshop of the Council and Assembly of the League of Nations. There was no doubt that for the purpose of preserving the peace of the world, International Unions and the focussing of them under one head should be a very great advantage.

In the able paper by Miss Sanger on the - New Labour Organisations -, he wished that there had been somewhat more of insistance on the duty of labour and less on its rights; in these hard times he would rather hear of a minimum day's labour, to - which all able-bodied people should be compelled, than of a maximum day's labour beyond which it is somewhat of a crime to work. - In his paper entitled - International Co-operation under the

League of Nations », Dr. Schuster reminded the conference that in the Covenant of the LEAGUE, all COMMITTEES, provided by the international bureaux already established, should be placed under the direction of the League if the parties of the Treaty by which they were established, consented to that course.

The Executive Committee of the Association considered the present time as opportune for the consideration of the question as to the possiblity of the extension of the existing schemes of international co-operation and the widening oftheir spheres of influence.

Under the term « International Unions », DR, Schuster included ' all schemes of international co-operation for specific objects concerned with the peaceful activities of mankind and excessive centralisation of the various activities which they embody would not appear to be desirable.

The continuance of International Unions. subject to the modification brought about by the several treaties of peace, might be taken for granted and it only remained to be seen how the efficiency of the existing Inions might be included and whether the creation of new International Unions for the purposes which had hitherto not been dealt with internationally, ought to be advocated.

His aim was not to discuss details. but to show the necessity of maintaining all existing International Unions extending their sphere of action and of connecting their operations with the machinery of the League of Nations which will be so organised as to be able to form a centre for those Unions which at present were without a central establishment or at least so as to be able to act as a clearing station for mutual communications between the branches, and as an existing agency in the work of investigation and research.

The scope of the work of the International Law Association in connection with the establishment of International Unions was very extensive. It could establish standing Committees for the organisation of International Co-operation for juristic research and for practical purposes. Other subjects were the systemisation and . co-ordination of the work of Comparative Law the consideration of a new system of Public International LAW, resulting from the experience of the war, and such subjects as nationality and naturalisation in respect of which diversities now existing created difficulties which did not merely affect individuals, but might also be a source of public danger.
In « The New International Labour Organisation », Miss Sophy Sanger pointed to the fact that the Treaty of VERSAILLES, quite apart from the League of NATIONS, recognised the International Labour 26

Organisation and its existence had formed part of the Treaty with Germany and was not part of the Covenant. So that it might continue even if the League of Nations fell tothe ground. Germany and Austria had been admitted to the Labour ORGANISATION, before the Treaty of Peace had been concluded.
Miss Sanger described the proceedings at Washington and the matters which were agreed to there, which required to be embodied in Conventions to be adopted by the various legislatures.

After discussion, Dr. Schuster moved that a Committee be apointed for the purpose of considering and reporting to the next Conference as to (a) the methods by which international cooperation for common, economic, social and legal objects may be - extended and intensified ; (b) the question as to the possibility of bringing such unions into connection with the machinery of the League of Nations and as to the method by which such connection should if possible, be established.

This resolution was seconded by Sir Alfred Hopkinson and supported by Dr. BISSCHOP, Mr. J. Arthur BARRATT, Sir William J. COLLINS, K. C. V. O., D" Charlotte A. van MANEN, the Marquis A. CORSI, Mr. Wyndham BEWÈS, Dr G. M. W. JELLINGHAUS,
Professor G. W. J. Burns and Mr. C. de Wilde.

The Right Hon. the Earl of Reading was elected President of the Association. - Dr. Jitta and Mr. Justice Loder were elected Vice-Presidents for HOLLAND, and Dr. Jitta was elected President of the Conference to be held at the Hague on the 30" AUGUST, l92l.
The invitation of the Argentine Branch of the Association and of the Argentine Government to hold a Conference at Buenos Aires in 1922, was accepted. ce Sir H. Erle RICHARDS, K. C. S. I., K.

C., the Chichele Professor - of International Law at the University of OXFORD, presided over the Conference of « Aviation in Peace Time ». - The restriction of the discussion to aviation in peace, he said, did not mean that aviation in time of war was not a subject deserving the most thorough and complete consideration. It was a subject fraught with the most tremendous consequences, which would have to be considered by the Association and that at an early date.
If no restrictions were placed upon warfare in the air, then we should see, the moment war was declared, fleets of airships issuing from the belligerent countries on either side, devastating the

centres of population. That was a prospect too terrible to think of and when we came to deal with the Laws of War in regard to the air, some form of prohibition must be found. - Aviation in peace time also had its difficulties, which had to be faced and considered.

In referring to the sovereignty over the air, he pointed out that the International Law Association was the first learned body to advocate sovereignty over the air. The resolution passed at the Madrid Conference in 1913, had been accepted by every belligerent during the war, as a rule of practice, and had been adopted in the Air Navigation Convention of l919.

In a paper entitled - International Air Law in Time of Peace -, - Dr. HAZELTINE, Downing Professor of Law at the University of CAMBRIDGE, gave a valuable analysis of the Convention and the TREATY, with a clear summary of the existing law on the subject.

In a paper entitled - Some Comments on the Air Navigation CONVENTION, l9l9 -, Miss Dr. Lycklama à NIJEHOLT, who has already earned distinction by previous studies on this subject, makes some suggestions for further investigation of certain points.

She proposed, for instance, that the liability for damage by aeroplanes should be the same in every country. She raised the question of the nationality of corporate bodies, who might be registered as owners of aircraft. She also raised the question of the voting of the national representatives of the contracting States on the International Commission.

Lieutenant Colonel H. de WATTEVILLE, C. B. E., speaking from his experiences in the war, asserted that there was no stronger argument for the establishment of a League of Nations than the possibilities of air war in the future.
The whole plan of campaign on both sides at the end of the war, was nothing more or less than an attack upon the morale of the civil population.
Unless some kind of agreement, limiting such attacks that could be reached, we were faced with the enormous question of defending the United Kingdom against air attack.

One of the difficulties in the problem of disarmament lay in the fact that in the case of aeroplanes, it was the pilot who counted for more than the machine. Every pilot in civil life was a potential war pilot. - The conversion of a commercial aeroplane for war purposes, was only a question of a quarter of an hour's work.
Another difficulty was that of espionage. Were these potential

war pilots for instance, to be allowed to fly over this country by night ? It was useless to prohibit certain points. Such a course was merely put to advertise the points where we did not want anybody to know what was going on, unless some limitations were imposed. .

Mr. J. Arthur Barratt moved, and Mr. Perowne seconded, that the matters referred to in the papers of Dr. Hazeltine Dr. Lycklama à NIJEHOLT, together with any other points arising out ot the Convention of OCTOBER, l9l9, be referred to the Aviation Law Committee of the Association for their consideration and recommendations, and that such Committee do report to the next Conference with an instruction that so far as possible the Committee co-operate with the Air Ministry of H. M. Government and other Governments with whom the Association may be able to put themselves in touch.
2k 2k :

Even from this necessarily brief and inadequate summary of the Proceedings of the Portsmouth CONFERENCE, it will be seen that the Association has lived up to the traditions of the past. It shows that the members are still imbued with its original object of securing and maintaining the peace of the world by right rather than by might.

Their support of the League of Nations is a natural development of its advocacy of arbitration as a means of settling international disputes. - Whilst hoping that the League of Nations will prevent war, they recognise that war is still with us and that even when the present troubles have subsided, the possibility of war will still be with us. The Association therefore have wisely considered the means whereby, should wars in the future take place, the peculiar atrocities of the late war may not be extended or even repeated.

Dealing with such questions ofvital interest to the whole world, the Portsmouth Conference will be memorable in the annuals of the ASSOCIATION, not only for the subjects discussed, but from the impartial manner in which they were discussed by jurists, diplomats, naval and military officers from all parts of the world.
AS Lord Justice Younger observed to me, what most impressed him was the enthusiasm of those present and the spirit of harmony which prevailed.
HUGH H. L. BELLOT D. C. L.
III
CHRONIQUE DE LA SOCIÉTÉ DES NATIONS PREMIÈRES IMPRESSIONS D'ASSEMBLÉE.
Il n'est pas possible d'émettre dès maintenant un jugement sur ce que sera l'œuvre de l'Assemblée.

Une première impression se dégage pourtant de la première semaine de séances publiques : celle d'une extraordinaire vitalité. Comme le disait M. HYMANS, président de l'ASSEMBLÉE, au cours d'un interview, il y a là une force que l'on ne détruira plus jamais ; les peuples ont pris conscience de la nécessité de la coopération; ils ne se laisseront plus séparer.

On a beau dire, en effet, que cette assemblée n'est pas juridiquement un parlement international, mais une conférence diplomatique qui ne met en présence que des délégués de gouvernements ; jamais des diplomates n'ont parlé avec autant de liberté et autant de vigueur des questions d'intérêt général.

MM .Nansen ou lord Robert Cecil ne représentent pas seulement l'Afrique du sud et la NORVÈGE, et lorsque Don Harmodio Arias se fait l'éloquent défenseur de l'arbitrage obligatoire il ne s'inspire pas seulement des intérêts de la République de Panama ni des idées de ses habitants.

Envoyés de gouvernements différents, la plupart des délégués présents à l'Assemblée ont senti qu'ils ne devaient pas s'inspirer des intérêts de leur « circonscription électorale », mais qu'ils manqueraient à leur devoir s'ils ne cherchaient pas à réaliser dans une Société des Nations consolidée, les aspirations de l'humanité tout entière.

Et sans doute l'on n'évite pas une certaine contradiction, que n'ont pas manqué de souligner différents orateurs, en voyant M. BARNES, délégué du gouvernement britannique, adresser au nom de la classe ouvrière des critiques au Conseil! Mais cette contradiction est nécessaire et inhérente à l'évolution même qui doit conduire la Société des Nations à des formes de coopération plus étroites et plus efficaces.
A condition que l'évolution soit prudente !
Quelle que soit la satisfaction que cette liberté d'allure ait causée dans les milieux progressistes, ne dissimulons pas le danger que présenterait actuellement un relâchement trop

gramd des liens qui soumettent aux gouvernements, membres de la Société des NATIONS, les délégués à l'Assemblée. L'Assemblée doit être en état de prendre des décisions obligatoires pour les gouvernements. Elle est, et doit pour ce motif, rester une réunion officielle, et ce serait la vouer à l'impuissance que de la transformer en congrès pacifiste ou en assemblée interparlementaire. - Si cette nécessité est certaine lorsqu'il s'agit de l'ASSEMBLÉE, combien se présente-t-elle avec une apparence plus impérieuse encore, quand il s'agit du Conseil appelé à intervenir rapidement dans des conflits et qui doit pouvoir faire agir dans le sens de ses décisions l'autorité politique tout entière des membres de la Société qui y sont représentés.
La conciliation entre ces deux nécessités : impartialité des décisions et approbation complète par les gouvernements représentés nous paraît pouvoir être obtenue de la manière suivante.

Les gouvernements doivent se faire représenter non par des instruments dociles et passifs mais par des partisans décidés de la coopération internationale. Ceux-ci acceptent les instructions de leurs gouvernements, mais ces instruction doivent être le résultat d'un échange de vues entre gouvernement et délégués où ceux-ci sont admis à présenter et à défendre leurs idées. Les instructions doivent laisser le plus de liberté possible aux délégués et se borner à leur fixer les limites que paraissent nécessiter aux gouvernements les intérêts nationaux ou internationaux. ENFIN, les délégués tiennent autant que possible leurs gouvernements au courant des progrès de la discussion et sollicitent éventuellement des modifications aux instructions données.
Telle nous paraît devoir être la conception actuelle des rapports entre les Etats et leurs représentants à l'Assemblée et au Conseil.

A sa base se trouve le principe actuel : la Société des Nations n'est pas un sur-ETAT, pas une nouvelle personne de droit des gens, puisqu'elle n'a pas de volonté propre distincte de celle des membres qui la composent.

Mais on pressent l'évolution : pour les questions de procédure déjà, la majorité des voix de l'Assemblée engage tous les membres ; pour l'admission des nouveaux Etats il suffit de deux tiers des membres ; les amendements au pacte doivent réunir l'unanimité des membres du Conseil et deux tiers des membres de l'Assemblée.
Ce sont ces clauses qui feront craquer un jour l'ancien système international. La nouvelle personne de droit des gens se

dessine; il est impossible que « la volonté générale internationale », la conscience de l'intérêt général ne cherche pas un jour à s'affranchir de l'obstacle que la pusillanimité ou l'égoïsme de quelques-uns pourraient mettre au progrès de la coopération internationale qui est dans les vœux de la majorité.
Cette étape sera franchie à son heure.

Pour le moment on peut se réjouir sans réserve de ce que cette première réunion de l'Assemblée offre d'heureux présages. - ( )r pouvait craindre que l'Assemblée montrât vis-à-vis du Consei! de l'humeur ou de l'hostilité; il n'en a rien été. Tous les Ftats ont paru se rendre compte de la nécessité de se grouper autour du Conseil et de fortifier son autorité, afin de rendre som: action efficace.

Rien non plus d'un groupement des petits Etats contre les puissances principales. Le prestige de la France et de la Grande-Bretagne reste très grand, mais peut-être peut-on dès maintenant remarquer que les petits Etats paraissent devoir être moins souvent embarrassés que les grands d'intérêts politiques particuliers. Et l'on se demande à ce sujet si l'histoire ne devra pas renverser un jour la classification inaugurée à la dernière Conférence de la Paix qui divisait les Etats en puissances à intérêts particuliers et puissances à intérêts généraux.

Il faut reconnaître que le Conseil a rendu à l'Assemblée la monnaie de sa pièce, et n'a pas songé un moment à réduire son autorité. L'activité du Conseil au cours de l'année écoulée a été très librement discutée et le Conseil a même par l'intermédiaire officieux de M. Tittoni et plus récemment de M. Léon BOURGEOIS, fourni en quelque sorte des explications.

Le Conseil a d'autre part accueilli de très bonne grâce la coopération de l'Assemblée dans la recherche de mesures propres à secourir l'Arménie. Il semble qu'il consentira à ce qu'une commission permanente du budget soit nommée directement par l'Assemblée. Enfin il a accepté que des rapports lui soient demandés sur les amendements présentés au pacte et sur l'interprétation de l'article 18, pour la prochaine session de l'Assemblée. - Il est vrai que les rapports entre l'Assemblée et le. Conseil restent imprécis. Trouvera-t-on une formule pour les définir ?
Une commission a été désignée pour étudier la question.
Déjà M. HAGERUP, l'éminent juriste, qui représente la Norvège a cru pouvoir annoncer que fatalement on serait amené à considérer le Conseil comme gouvernement et l'Assemblée comme parlement.

Nous croyons que la distinction n'est pas entièrement exacte ; elle ne correspond pas du tout en effet aux compétences respectives des deux organismes, Assemblée et Conseil. Ce dernier n'est pas le pouvoir exécutif; il est le pouvoir permanent chargé de l'action continue, l'Assemblée ne se réunissant que de manière plus intermittente comme constituante et organe de contrôle. Si nous devions trouver dans nos organisations politiques internes une analogie, nous comparerions les rapports entre Conseil et Assemblée à ceux qu'a établis notre loi provinciale de 1836 entre la délégation permanente et le Conseil provincial.

Le contrôle ! Je sais que ce mot soulève des protestations et n'est-il pas en contradiction avec l'autorité du Conseil et aussi avec la représentation permanente au Conseil donnée aux grandes puissances ? Mais il ne faut pas confondre le principe du contrôle et ses manifestations. On peut se faire une idée des formes successives par lesquelles le contrôle de l'Assemblée pourra passer : vote de blâme; refus du budget; dans l'espèce aussi non réélection des membres non permanents. Un conflit entre l'Assemblée et le Conseil pourrait amener aussi le sacrifice, de la part des principales puissances, des personnes qui les représentent et seraient censées les avoir mal informées.
